titleStmt.title: Aphorismes of state or Certaine secret articles for the re-edifying of the Romish Church agreed vpon, and approued in councell, by the Colledge of Cardinalls in Rome, shewed and deliuered vnto Pope Gregory the 15. a little before his death. Whereunto is annexed a censure vpon the chiefe points of that which the cardinalls had concluded. By Tho. Scott. Very needfull and profitable for all those, who are desirous to vnderstand the euent of the restitution of the Palatinate: and of the state of the Prince-Electors, of Saxon and Brandenburgh, in the behalfe of the clergie in Rome. Fit for the Brittish nation, especially to take notice of, that they may euidently see, the issue of all our treaties, ambassages, and promises, with other hopes depending: wherein we haue beene long held in suspence, and are still like to be, to our vnrecouerable losse. Faithfully translated according to the Latine, and Netherlandish Dutch, into English.
Nieuwe, ongehoorde, vreemde en secrete artijckelen, tot herbouwinge vande Roomsche Kercke-standt, by het Collegie der Cardinalen binnen Romen. English
titleStmt.author: Scott, Thomas, 1580?-1626.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: APHORISMES OF STATE: OR Certaine ≈øecret ARTICLES for the reedifying of the ROMISH CHVRCH agreed vpon, and approued in Councell, by the Colledge of Cardinalls in Rome, ≈øhewed and deliuered vnto Pope Gregory the 15. a little before his death. Whereunto is annexed a cen≈øure vpon the chiefe points of that which the Cardinalls had concluded.
By THO. SCOTT.

Very needfull and profitable for all tho≈øe, who are de≈øirous to vnder≈øtand the euent of the re≈øtitution of the PALATINATE: And of the ≈øtate of the Prince-Electors, of Saxon and Brandenburgh, in the behalfe of the Clergie in Rome. Fit for the Britti≈øh Nation, e≈øpecially to take notice of, that they may euidently ≈øee, the i≈ø≈øue of all our Treaties, Amba≈ø≈øages, and Promi≈øes, with other hopes depending: wherein we haue beene long held in ≈øu≈øpence, and are ≈øtill like to be, to our vnrecouerable lo≈ø≈øe.
Faithfully Tran≈ølated according to the Latine, and Netherlandi≈øh Dutch, into Engli≈øh.
Printed at Vtrech. 1624.

div.head: The fir≈øt Article.
div.p: WHereas Maximilian the Duke of Bauaria, for the e≈øtabli≈øhing the ≈øtate of his Prince-Elector≈øhip, hath ≈øought vnto the authority of the Apo≈øtolicall ≈øeat, thereby hath the Apo≈øtolicall Church obtained oportunity, to recouer their lo≈øt obedience in the denied Eccle≈øia≈øticall iuri≈ødiction.

div.head: The 2. Article.
div.p: SInce the Pope of Rome by meanes of the pre≈øent Duke of Bauaria, as being the mo≈øt obedient ≈øonne of the Church, may obtaine againe the Rights, which for the≈øe two hundred yeares and more, haue beene lo≈øt in the con≈øtituting of certaine things, and orders in the Empire belonging to the Church, it will bee a very ≈ømall labour, to plucke the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of the Church goods, which depends vpon the Eccle≈øia≈øticall rights, out of the hands of the Hereticks.

div.head: The 3. Article.
div.p: WHereas the Duke of Bauaria, according to the e≈øpeciall Oath, made vnto the Church, hath an earne≈øt de≈øire, to re≈øtore againe the Eccle≈øia≈øticall State, as it was before the time of Pope Gregory the eleuenth, The Hereticks (who are the temporall Arme of the Empire) ≈øhall be bound to re≈øtore againe tho≈øe goods which they haue po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed ≈øince the pa≈ø≈øa wi≈øh tran≈ø-action.

div.head: The 4. Article.
div.p:
SInce that it properly appertaiueth to the Church to di≈øcerne and take notice of the ≈øtate and order of the Empire, therefore
tho≈øe Hereticks which denie this antiquity, and the rights of the Church in the ≈øtate and order of the Empire, which now by the Duke of Bauaria ≈øhall be ree≈øtabli≈øhed in time to come, are not to be tollerated.

div.head: The 5. Article.
div.p: SInce that Pope Leo the third, had that power in re≈øpect of the here≈øie, to cut off, and ≈øeperate the Ea≈øterne authority from the We≈øterne; and to plucke that from the Grecians: wherefore ≈øhall not the Pope now haue the ≈øame power, to take the Prince Elector≈øhip from the Pal≈øgraue, as being an Arch-hereticke, and tran≈øport the ≈øame vnto the Duke of Bauaria, the mo≈øt obedient ≈øonne of the Church.

div.head: The 6. Article.
div.p: SInce that the divul≈øion of the Ea≈øterne Empire, from the We≈øterne, which was performed by the mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed Pope, Leo the third, hath continued ≈øo firme and ≈øacred euen to this very time: that although the We≈øterne Empire hath often times beene voyd of a po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor, was neuer as yet vnited vnto the Ea≈øterne Empire, nor the lawes of the one in the Prouinces of the other were euer of force: wherefore then ≈øhall not the divul≈øion of the Prince Electors dignities of the Pal≈øgraue that arch-hereticke, be maintained vpon the mo≈øt Catholique Duke of Bauaria, in the like ≈øanctity of perpetuity and ≈øtability, by the Pope and the Holy league.

div.head: The 7. Article.
div.p:
SInce that the tran≈øport of the Empire from the Grecians vnto the French, performed with ≈øuch a free arme, and ≈øuch an actiue power by Pope Leo. The Grecian Emperours them≈øelues, although they were the ≈øtronge≈øt, dur≈øt neuer oppugne the ≈øame, nay haue many times & often very ≈øignificantly commended and firmely kept the ≈øame, in like manner the ability not the oppo≈øition of the arch Heretick, the Saxon who is yet remaining, may not hinder, much le≈ø≈øe make oppo≈øition to the tran≈øport of the Prince Electors dignity, vnto the mo≈øt Catholique Duke of Bauavia: in regard that he as being an Heretique, and not knowing the
≈øanctity, nor the antiquity of the rights originall of the Empire, and ignorant of the lawes and priuiledges thereof, may not enioy that right.

div.head: The 8. Article.
div.p: WHen as Fredericke the fir≈øt, according to the will and plea≈øure of Pope Alexander the third, was detruded from the Emperiall ≈øeate, then Emanuell Comnennus pre≈øented both men and money vnto the Pope again≈øt Fredericke, to the end the Grecian Church might bee vnited to the Latines: by which vndoubtedly he confe≈ø≈øeth, that to e≈øtabli≈øh and fortifie the Popes cutting off, and tran≈øport, and the vniting of one Kingdome with another, was forbidden, all men what≈øoeuer, ≈øaue onely the Pope, who had fir≈øt ≈øeperated them; ≈øo in like manner the≈øe things like as they al≈øo be, ≈øo is it true that the Pope with the Holy league, are bound to employ all their power again≈øt the Arch-Hereticke the Saxon, and all tho≈øe Rebels that depend vpon him: that the Sanctity of the Apo≈øtolicall ≈øtoole, and the Antiquity of the Romi≈øh Empire in the tran≈øport of the Prince Electors dignity, might be pre≈øerued and maintained.

div.head: The 9. Article.
div.p: AFter Pope Leo haue other Popes al≈øo, onely by the authority of their Chaire, very often tran≈øported the ≈øayde We≈øterne Empire from one Nation to another; wherefore then may not the Pope by the ≈øame authority of the Chaire of Rome, plucke the Prince Electors dignities out of the hands of the Heretickes, and tran≈øport the ≈øame to the Catholique Princes, to the end that the ≈øacred E≈ø≈øence of the Romi≈øh Empire, by the extirpation of Hereticks be againe e≈øtabli≈øhed.

div.head: The 10. Article.
div.p:
VVHereas in all right, Pope Boniface the eight, vnto whom the ≈øupreame authority in the Church belonged,
would not admit that Albert the fir≈øt of that name, Emperour of the Romans, by right of inheritance might come to the Empire, like as he had ≈øought both for him≈øelfe and for his po≈øterity and ≈øucce≈ø≈øours, but onely by election: In like manner may the Pope, the Emperour, and the holy league, without violating the Apo≈øtolicall ≈øeate, which alwayes to be kept ≈øacred in her antiquity, mu≈øt be defended, not to ≈øuffer the Saxon and the Brandenburgher, that they ≈øhould ≈øeeke to draw the authority of the Antiquity in the tran≈øport of the Elector≈øhip from the Chaire of Rome, to bring the ≈øame to the Colledge of the Prince Electors.

div.head: The 11. Article.
div.p: PHilip King of the Francks, ≈øent Amba≈ø≈øadours to Abignon vnto Pope Clemens the fifth: That they very humbly ≈øhould entreate him, that hee would re≈øtore the Empire againe to the French, vnder whom before it had bin. Then did the Pope ≈øend Amba≈ø≈øadors vnto the Prince Electors, by whom hee commanded them, that they ≈øhould chu≈øe Henry of Lutzenburgh Emperour: And that if they did the contrary, that they ≈øhould incurre greate danger, and ≈øhould forfait the Empire, and the right of their Election vnto others for euer; whereupon they pre≈øently a≈ø≈øembled, and elected Henry Emperour. From all this very plainely appeareth, that the French a≈ø≈øuredly knew, that it was in the Popes power to e≈øtabli≈øh the Emperiall command in their Kingdome, and to tran≈øport from the Germanes the Empire and the right of the Election: and therefore may the Pope according to the plenitude of his power, no longer v≈øe conniuence, when as the≈øe Arch-Hereticks, the Saxon and the Brandenburgher, would throw downe into hell, the antiquity and order of the Empire.

div.head: The 12. Article.
div.p:
IT is in the Popes hands, as in all Hi≈øtories appeareth to renew the Emperour in their Empire, to tran≈øport the authority of one Nation vnto another, and vtterly to aboli≈øh the right of Election: how wickedly and vngodly then doth the Saxon, in labouring to plucke the ≈øayd power from the Chaire of Rome, and to vnite the ≈øame vnto the Colledge of the Prince Electors? By this
meanes the Pope of Rome and the Emperour may expect, that from this permi≈ø≈øion the re≈øt of the Arch-Hereticks, the Saxon and the Brandenburgher, may change the E≈ø≈øence of the holy Church, and of the Empire, into an abhominable and cur≈øed mon≈øter.

div.head: The 13. Article.
div.p: SInce that Wence≈ølaus by rea≈øon of his follies, by the Prince-Electors, was depo≈øed from the Emperiall ≈øeat, and contrarily Robert Pal≈øgraue of the Rhine, by the commaund and authority of Pope Boniface the 9. a≈øcended to that high dignity. In like manner al≈øo is the Pal≈øgraue that Arch-hereticke, becau≈øe he had committed high trea≈øon, and had di≈øturbed the Common-peace of the Emperour and the Empire, detruded from his Prince-Elector≈øhip: And contrarily for the recouering of the Antiquity, the Emperour with the ≈øacred and true Prince-Electors, as ≈øonne obedient to the Church, and diligent in maintaining Antiquity by Commi≈ø≈øion from the Pope, hath promoted Maximilian Duke of Bauaria in all right vnto that high degree of Prince-Elector≈øhip.

div.head: The 14. Article.
div.p: SO that by the Authority of the Apo≈øtelicall ≈øeate, the power of Electing an Emperour, and a Prince Elector: is drawne into the number of ≈øeauen Princes: yet whereas according to the Conce≈ø≈øion of Gregory the 5. it appertained vnto all the Princes of Germany: al≈øo by the ≈øame plenitude of power, it is lawfull for the Pope to cut off the Dignity of the Prince-elector≈øhippe, from the Pal≈øgraue and his heires, and to tran≈øport the ≈øame vnto the Duke of Bauaria.

div.head: The 15. Article.
div.p: THe plenitude of the power of the Apo≈øtolicall ≈øeate, is prooued by the publique documents, as is the Election of Rudolph of Hab≈øburgh, Adolph, Henry the 7: Charles the 4. Wence≈ølaus, and Rupertus, who had no other ≈øtability, but from the grant and con≈øent of Nicholas the third, Boniface the 8. Clemens the 5. Clemens the 6. Gregory the 11. and Boniface the 9. which publique documents are kept with the Writings of the Apo≈øtolicall ≈øeate.

div.head: The 16. Article.
div.p: TO the end that the Antiquity of the Empire may the better bee manife≈øted, that the Pope and the Church hath onely the power to take notice, di≈øcerne, and to di≈øpo≈øe of the affaires of the Empire: Therefore the Emperour is Crowned with the Crowne by the Pope, who therein hath the highe≈øt authority, and this worke effected, then is he e≈øtabli≈øht in the Emperiall ≈øeate: Therefore all Doctors doe agree herein, that hee that is Crowned by the Pope, hath the power onely to beare the title of Emperour and Augu≈øtus: To ≈øigne with the ≈øigne of the golden Bull, and to take vpon him the admini≈øtration of the Empire: and when the Prince is not crowned by the Pope, he is rightly forbidden to v≈øe the ≈øame.

div.head: The 17. Article.
div.p: AT what time a great contention was ri≈øen betweene Charles the balde King of the Francks, and his brother Lodowicke in the behalfe of the Empire. Then pre≈øently Charles po≈øted vnto Rome, and ≈øo with gifts and entreaties obtained the Crowne: And therefore Carelus Calvin. according to the forme of Antiquity, the Pope onely hath the power to take notice of matters of the Empire: and therefore the Germane Hereticks doe very ill in ≈øaying, That the ≈øame belongeth to the Colledge of the Prince Electors.

div.head: The 18. Article.
div.p: SInce that Fredericke the fir≈øt, by the Bi≈øhop of Bamberghen, required the Crowne of the Empire from Pope Adrian the 4. (where the words vnder-written are v≈øed and placed to expre≈ø≈øe the ≈øame ≈øence) from whence very plainely appeareth, that hee that receiueth not the Crowne out of the Popes hand, is in very deede no Emperour. Therefore mo≈øt holy Father, fulfill without any longer delay, that which Maximilion the Duke of Bauaria wanteth in the plenitude of the Dignity of his Prince-Elector≈øhip, that the ≈øame may be accompli≈øhed by your Holine≈ø≈øes liberality, to the end the Empire may bee reduced and brought into its olde fa≈øhion againe.

div.head: The 19. Article.
div.p: SInce that in the di≈øpo≈øing and ordering of the affaires of the Empire, the Popes re≈øpect onely extendeth ≈øo farre, that it now and then hath beene vexed, ≈øuppre≈øt, nay hath beene wholy and totally circumuented and defrauded; like as many Hi≈øtories doe te≈øtifie, what hath pa≈ø≈øed betweene Pope Gregory the 7. and the Emperour Henry the 4. betweene Pope Alexander, and the Emperour Fredericke: the fir≈øt, between Pope Innocent the third, and the Emperour Ottaman the fourth, betweene Pope Innocent the fourth, and the Emperour Fredericke betweene Pope Iohn the 21. and the Emperour Lodowick the 4. betweene Pope Boniface the 9. and the Emperour Wence≈ølaus. By the ≈øame re≈øpect hath the Pope that vndoubted right to take notice of the affaires of the Emperour, and to di≈øcerne thereof, and not the Colledge of the prince Electors.

div.head: The 20. Article.
div.p: SInce that the power of the Electing the Emperour, was not purcha≈øed for money by the prince Electors, nor obtained by force of Armes, nor enioyed by right of Inheritance, nor befalne vnto them by the hands of the Emperors, but is de≈øcended from the authority of the Apo≈øtolicall ≈øeat: Therefore it is not lawfull for the Germane Arch-hereticks, now at this pre≈øent to beleeue any otherwi≈øe, thereby to mole≈øt the Antiquity and Sanctity of the Empire.

div.head: The 21. Article.
div.p:
WHen as for a long time the cu≈øtome of Electing the Emperour had beene in v≈øe, according to the con≈øtitution of Pope Gregory the 5. by the Interce≈øsion of all the Chiefe≈øt and princes of Germany, and that many troubles and deui≈øions aro≈øe by the great diuer≈øity of voyces in their Election; The Empire is at la≈øt become to nought; So that the Chiefes and Princes with one accord (according to the decree and approbation of the apo≈øtolicall ≈øeat) were agreed, that all the power which was graunted vnto them, all of pope Gregory the 5. ≈øhould de≈øcend vnto
≈øixe Princes onely; viz. to three ≈øpirituall and three temporall, vnto whom afterwards the ≈øeauenth was adioyned, and ≈øolemnly concluded, that of the≈øe alone, without admitting any other thereunto (from henceforth the Emperour ≈øhould be cho≈øen) although they were of the like faculty, power, and authority.

div.head: The 22. Article.
div.p: LIke as in former time the Election was performed by vertue of the graunt of Pope Gregory the fift. The ≈øame ≈øhall now at this pre≈øent (by the ≈øame power proceeding from the good plea≈øure of the Popes tran≈øport) be effected by the ≈øeauen. And like as in olde time, the Popes commanded all the Chiefes and Princes of Germany, that they ≈øhould chu≈øe an Emperour, euen ≈øo at this time when neede requireth, it ≈øhall be lawfull for the Pope to commaund the ≈øeauen Prince Electors, who doe repre≈øent the A≈ø≈øembly of all the princes there. And like as the ≈øeauen Prince Electors doe enioy a like power that authority of right, which in olde time the Princes of Germany enioyed: in like manner the Pope doe enioy wholly that authority which they had in the time of that A≈ø≈øembly, in regard that through proce≈ø≈øe of yeares, or length of time, the vigour of the Church demini≈øheth not, nor the rights of the Apo≈øtolicall ≈øeat doe wax decrepit: How great then is the ignorance of tho≈øe Doctors and Councellours of the Germane Arch-heretickes, which neither know the antiquity nor the Rights: But according to their malicious conceit, are not a≈øhamed to peruert the Antiquity and Sanctity of the Empire into nouelty, and to bring order into confu≈øion.

div.head: The 23. Article.
div.p:
SInce then it hath beene very amply proued, and ≈øhewed to his Holine≈ø≈øe, that the power as well of the new as of the olde Prince Electors to Elect Emperours, hath beene obtained by no other meanes, but from the mo≈øt high Apo≈øtolicall ≈øeat, which may be approued by the Writings of the mo≈øt famous Authors, as Iacob Winphilingis, Krantzius, Naucleri, Carion, Auentine, Cu≈øpinianus, and other Tran≈ømontanian Writings, omiting the Italian Doctors, becau≈øe that they in this point of controuer≈øie, might peraduenture come in ≈øu≈øpition to be corrupted, and by that
meanes might be reiected, of the Germane Heretickes. Therefore it is, The re≈øt that ≈øhould follow, mu≈øt be taken from the former. &c.

div.head: The 24. Article.
div.p: SInce the ≈øeauen Prince Electors, by the publick proofes of writings, ≈øub≈øcribed with their owne hands and Seales, doe not deny that the faculty of Electing Emperours, is de≈øcended vnto them from the Apo≈øtolicall ≈øeat, & if the ignorant Councellours of Saxon and Brandenburgh, will not beleeue the ≈øame, the Writings them≈øelues ≈øhall be produced and laid open before them, which doe approue the ≈øame, dated in the yeare 1279. when Nicholas the third was Pope and Rudolphus. Hub≈øpurgen≈øis was Emperour, which are whole and good, in parchment, remaining with the Secretarie of the Ca≈øtle of Saint Angelo: where the ≈øeauen Prince Electors mo≈øt of them v≈øe the≈øe wordes. The mother Church of Rome in times pa≈øt, as with a naturall loue embracing Germany, hath as with a pre≈øent of temporall dignities honoured the ≈øame, with that which is aboue all names, onely as temporally vpon the earth, planting Princes therein, as godly Trees, and watring the ≈øame with a ≈øingular grace, and hath giuen vnto them that growth of worldly power; that they being ≈øupported by the authority of the ≈øame Church, as a choy≈øe and famous plant, may cau≈øe to ≈øpring or grow vp by their Election, him who hath the reynes of the Romane Empire in his hand. Therefore it is, Here lacketh ≈øomthing which is to be conceiued out of that which goeth before. &c.

div.head: The 25. Article.
div.p: THe ≈øeauen Prince Electors mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe to haue this power from the Apo≈øtolicall ≈øeat, like as ≈øufficiently is proued in the former Article. And contrarily no man can take away the ≈øame; without the authority and con≈øent of the ≈øame Apo≈øtolicall ≈øeat. If it be taken from any, as being robd therof, it mu≈øt not be e≈øteemed as lawfully done, and that dignitie which after that manner is ≈øo taken from one, and tran≈øported to another without the Popes con≈øent and authority hath no vigour, in regard the ≈øame is taken and giuen by them, whom in all right it is forbidden. Therefore if it be be≈øtowed vpon any man after this manner, in proce≈ø≈øe of time, taking the right title, he ≈øhall not keepe the ≈øame.

div.head: The 26 Article.
div.p: SInce that the tran≈øport of the dignities of the Prince-Elector≈øhip vnto this pre≈øent line of Saxon, is not e≈øtabli≈øht by the mo≈øt holy Apo≈øtolicall ≈øeate; Therefore the Pope and the Emperour for the dealing of the tran≈øport of the Elector≈øhip vnto the Duke of Bauaria, ≈øhall not once be moued, but his exception again≈øt the Tran≈øport, ≈øhall not be e≈øteemed for no exception: for that which is lawfully done, and ≈øimply is not done, is all one.

div.head: The 27. Article.
div.p: SInce that the tran≈øport of the dignities of the Prince-Elector≈øhip, is pa≈ø≈øed vnto Maximilian Duke of Bauaria, and is confirmed by the mo≈øt holy Father, Therefore it is no longer in the Emperour, nor in the King of Spaines power, to place that Arch-Heritick the Pal≈øgraue, or his heires in that dignity and dominion, out of which their Father is ca≈øt, nor to place him againe in the Elector≈øhip, in regard that the≈øe Controuer≈øies doe belong to the mo≈øt holy Apo≈øtolicall ≈øeat, and neither to the Emperour, nor the King of Spaine.

div.head: The 28. Article.
div.p: SInce that the Pope hoth confirmed the tran≈øport of the Elector≈øhip: ≈øo is that demand (which the King of England, the King of Denmarke, the Saxon, and the Brandenburgher, of the re≈øtitution of the Pal≈øgraue into his dignities and Elector≈øhip) which they ≈øeeke of the Emperor very vnrea≈øonable: for the requiring thereof is nothing el≈øe, but the detruding of the Apo≈øtolicall ≈øeat (from the right of her Maie≈øtie, and to attribute vnto the Emperour the fundamentall originall, contrary to the antiquity and Sanctity of the Church and Empire: And therefore the holy Father ≈øhall be warie, that from ≈øuch like conniuence there ari≈øeth not a greater di≈øcommodity to the farther ruine of the Church.

div.head: The 29. Article.
div.p:
TO the end then that the E≈ø≈øence of the Church may be pre≈øerued in her Antiquity and Sanctity: The mo≈øt illu≈øtrious
Prelates, the Cardinalls, with one con≈øent and accord haue ≈øworne, that the Holy Father hauing permitted the confirmation, on Maximilian the Duke of Bavaria: may not reuoke the ≈øame without preiudice of the mo≈øt holy Apo≈øtolicall ≈øeat, and are bound by the lawes of God, ≈øimply to maintaine the afore≈øaid Duke of Bauaria with one common hand, with conioyned power of the whole Church, and with force of Armes, in the dignities of the Prince-Elector≈øhip.

div.head: Here followeth the Cen≈øure, or Con≈øideration vpon the afore≈øaid Articles.
div.p: HEre are pre≈øented vnto vs 29. Articles, from the Prelates of the Romi≈øh Church, who≈øe Elegancie is not much to be commended, and doe tend to the preiudice of Germany: for the better examination whereof, we will cour≈øe through all the members or particulars, and to the end that no man may be bewitched therewith, we will admini≈øter vnto the ≈øimple an Antidote again≈øt this poy≈øon.
The beginning ≈øhall be of the three fir≈øt Articles, wherein the Clergy of Rome doe imagine vnto them≈øelues a mo≈øt excellent growth as well of the Iuri≈ødiction, as of the Temporall goods.

To ≈øpeake in order of both the≈øe: I ≈øay the Pope for as much as he is Pope, hath no Iuri≈ødiction at all, but for as much as he is enriched by the liberality of Princes, he hath al≈øo his owne lands, and
hath a certaine Iuri≈ødiction, which is well to be vnder≈øtoode in his owne lands: But in the Empire where he hath no place among≈øt the Princes of the Empire: no Iuri≈ødiction may be allowed him, without demini≈øhing of the Emperiall Maie≈øtie: Let no man ≈øuffer him≈øelfe once to be moued for that which hath bin ≈øo long ≈øaid, that the Pope of Rome is in the place of Chri≈øt here vpon earth. Chri≈øt him≈øelfe denied that his Kingdome was of this world. The Di≈øciple is not mightier then his Ma≈øter, nor the ≈øeruant greater then his Lord.

What is more euident and plaine, then that which Chri≈øt him≈øelfe ≈øaith. Let the Kings of the Nations beare rule, but with you it mu≈øt not be ≈øo: neither is that firmer that they hope for the victory, from the triumph, and other proofes, wherewith they haue alwayes defended their cau≈øe, that Chri≈øt ≈øaid, All power is giuen me in heauen and in earth: Maldonatus refuteth this with the≈øe words. Chri≈øt ≈øpeaketh not here of all power, but of that which he gaue to the Apo≈øtles: that is of the power to obtaine and gather together his ≈øpirituall Kingdome, for which bu≈øine≈ø≈øe hee ≈øent out the Apo≈øtles; like as temporall Princes are carefull of their temporall goods, ≈øo are they al≈øo of their Iuri≈ødictions. Here auaileth that which the olde Father Bernard wrote to Pope Eugenius, in his fir≈øt booke of Ob≈øeruations, Your power is ouer offences or ≈øinnes, and not ouer po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions. The≈øe ba≈øe and earthly things haue their Iudges, Kings and Princes of the earth; wherefore doe≈øt thou enter vpon other mens iuri≈ødictions? Wherefore doe≈øt thou thru≈øt thy Sickle or Sythe into another mans Harue≈øt? Moreouer, he ≈øaith in his eleuenth booke, Dominion was forbiden the Apo≈øtles, dare≈øt thou then v≈øe it (A Lord) the Apo≈øtle≈øhip, or an Apo≈øtolicall per≈øon dominion, verily both the≈øe are forbiden you, if you will enioy both the≈øe at once. Therefore asketh Ho≈øtien≈øis, what ≈øhall we ≈øay of that which concerneth the Pope in worldly or temporall affaires? whereunto he maketh an≈øwere, with his Lord Innocentius, that vnto him, viz. the Pope, it concerned nothing at all. The ≈øame al≈øo may de read by Iohn Parien≈øis, in the tenth Chapter of the power of Kings and Popes. This is long agoe tolde vnto them,
but they giue it no audience, from hence ari≈øeth the Engli≈øh complaint by Mathew Paris, where hee treateth of Henry the third. That it is ≈øufficiently knowne and found, that the wrath of God is falne vpon the Romi≈øh Church, becau≈øe their Magi≈øtrate and Regent, doe not diligently apply them≈øelues for the denotion of the people, nor for the gaining of ≈øoules; but to purcha≈øe Reuenues, and to ≈øcrape money together.

Other Nations v≈øed very grieuou≈øly to complaine thereof, and that with good rea≈øon, e≈øpecially Germany, who≈øe Princes long agoe ≈øeeking remedy hereof, were not very acceptable, who could neuer ≈øatisfie the Romi≈øh Clergie, with riches and dignities: from this vn≈øatiable gulfe, al≈øo ari≈øeth that they in the third Article, de≈øire to cut off the conditions for their aduantage, which for the common peace ≈øake, were receiued aboue ≈øeauenty yeares ≈øince at Pa≈ø≈øow. But it is not in the Popes power, not in the Clergie, to breake that which was concluded by a generall Councell of the States, where the Authority of Charles entertained.

Heere followeth the Cen≈øure vppon the ≈øecond part, which extendeth it ≈øelfe farre larger then the fir≈øt, in regard that it not onely ≈øheweth the Cardinali≈øh Prince, but that which lyeth next vnder. This afore-≈øaid part containeth 20. Articles, in which they with the like proofes doe proceede, as yet ≈øeemeth: yet their obiect indeede is ≈øomething el≈øe, more then in the former. In which it ≈øeemeth to be ≈øufficient to Michael Lonigus: That if the Duke of Bauaria could but be per≈øwaded, that hee would ≈øeeke for the con≈øent of the Pope, in tho≈øe dignities where he was honoured. In ≈øuch manner the chiefe≈øt Cardinals doe take the reynes of good rea≈øon too too long into their hands; Nay, as Phacton vpon the Waggon of their Auarice, to the great danger of the world, and more e≈øpecially of Germany, doe ride out of the common rout of the Popes: like as if it were a matter of no moment, to pronounce ≈øuch an horrible ≈øentence of the Tran≈øport of the Elector≈øhip
of the Pal≈øgraue, and the occa≈øion thereof: whereof we will not now di≈øpute, and ≈øo they fall aboord the Prince-Electors of Saxon and Brandenburgh in the behalfe of the Rights of the Election: what is it el≈øe but with the like thunderbolt to da≈øh the heads of the ≈øacred Empire? they ≈øay they are Heretickes: It is now no time to enquire after here≈øie, but rather ≈øoundly to di≈øpute, whether that a Bi≈øhop like as hee hath right to excommunicate a man for here≈øie; Whether therefore hee hath the power al≈øo to rob and ≈øpoile a man of his dignities and meanes? verily therein is great difference: Chri≈øt commaunded that the excommunicated ≈øhould be counted as an Heathen or Publican: but in no place willeth hee that men ≈øhould rob the Heathens or Publicans of their Authority, or ≈øhould ≈øpoile them of their goods. Chri≈øt him≈øelfe paid Tole vnto the publicanes, and by his example, hath ≈øhewed vs the way what we ≈øhould doe. The Apo≈øtles liued vnder Heatheni≈øh Emperours, and were obedient to their lawes: in like manner al≈øo were all their Succe≈ø≈øors: nay the Apo≈øtles being obedient, v≈øed to pray to God for them: There ≈øaith Tertullian in his Analogie, in the thirtieth Chapter, wee inuoke the eternall God for the pro≈øperity of the Emperour, praying that he may haue a long life, a peacefull gouernment, an e≈øtabli≈øht habitation, ≈øtrong Armies, faithfull Councellours, and a peacefull world: When Iulian left Chri≈øtianity, and betooke him≈øelfe to Heatheni≈øme, did the Chri≈øtians then detrude him forth of his Empire? When they heare of this, then will they contend with later examples, ≈øaying, Wherefore then may not the Pope, by the ≈øame right for here≈øie, tran≈øport the dignity of the Prince-Elector≈øhip vnto another, ≈øince that Pope Leo the third, for the ≈øame occa≈øion tran≈øported Empire from the Grecians vpon the Francks? This is that Achilles which ≈øo boa≈øts in the Colledge of the Cardinalls, but yet he is not ≈øtrong enough to take in our Citie of Elium. They abu≈øe them≈øelues exceedingly with this example; fir≈øt from the Act of the Pope, they conclude the iu≈øtne≈ø≈øe of the Act, if we may ≈øo driue our Arguments, there is no Act of any
man, but it may be found fault withall: they erre al≈øo herein, that they affirme that to be done, which was neuer done.

We know it all of vs, that the Empire was tran≈øported, but withall that it was done by the councell of Rome, as al≈øo all Italy con≈øented thereunto, either priuatly or publikely. Of the we≈øterne people I will pa≈ø≈øe ouer in ≈øilence; They ≈øay againe that we haue many Writers, which make repetition of that which Leo did; who denieth that: but they commend Leo, as being one of the chiefe≈øt citizens, and ≈øo had the greate≈øt re≈øpect of any man in the Citty: they commend him al≈øo as being Bi≈øhop of Rome, who with his hands was to ≈øet vp the crowne, as being a ≈øign or repre≈øentation of the Empire; Therefore the≈øe writers were in no here≈øie, becau≈øe they meant that either Leo did the ≈øame alone, or el≈øe principally could haue done it. Many other who are no le≈ø≈øe in number, nor in re≈øpect then the≈øe, doe relate vnto vs the cleane contrary: they ≈øay expre≈øly, that the ≈øame was done and performed according to the decree & will, as is afore≈øaid of the Councell of Rome.
Sigebertus≈øaith in the yeare 801: The Romans now, who long agoe had withdrawne their affections from the Con≈øtantinopolitan Emperour, as then finding very good opportunitie, becau≈øe that a woman, when the Emperour Con≈øtantine was depriued of his ≈øight, gouerned them by his Son: then proclaimed they with one accord the Emperour Charles for their Emperour, they crowned him by the hand of Pope Leo, they ≈øtiled him Emperour and Augu≈øtus. A popi≈øh writer Theodoricus de Niem, who afterwards was Bi≈øhop of Verden, ≈øaith, about the very time of the Coronation the people of Rome made a Law according to the old cu≈øtome, but it was very trouble≈øome to recollect all things that happened ≈øo often: therefore the ≈øentence, right and power of the Empire, was left vnto the Emperour as we finde it written: then the people of Rome tran≈øported all this vnto Charles, &
gaue vnto him all their right and powor.

Blondus al≈øo in his fir≈øt book, decad 2: and Aneas Siluius, or Pius 2. in Blondus his ≈øhort relation: al≈øo Iacobus Wymphelingies, in his ≈øhort relation of the people of Rome, in the xi. Chapter, doe affirme that the Coronation by Leo, was performed and done with the knowledge, and at the entreatie of the people of Rome. The≈øe are the wordes of Onuphrius Panuimus in fa≈øtis: Leo by the con≈øent of the people of Rome, and at the entreatie of the clergie of Rome, proclameth Charles Emperour. So that from the≈øe and others who affirme that it was done by the Councell, and the people of Rome; mu≈øt tho≈øe writers be interpreted, that they doe not confirme, nor yet deny the ≈øame?

How much more is it to beleeue that which is confirmed by witne≈ø≈øes, which is denied by none: then not to beleeue tho≈øe which doe confirme the ≈øame, becau≈øe that all of them do not affirme, although there be no body that doe deny the ≈øame: for after this manner writeth Michell Coccimmus very well, in his booke of the tran≈øport of the Empire, we mu≈øt beleeue that the ≈øame tran≈øport was performed, and had his power or operation from the con≈øent and authoritie of the Romans, and other people of Italy. That which Innocentius the 3. wrote vnto Bartold Duke of Zaringe, doth not contradict the ≈øame: That the apo≈øtolicall ≈øeate of Rome, tran≈øported the Roman Empire vnto the per≈øon of the famous Charles from the Grecians vnto the Germanes, for in this wee con≈øent: That the Apo≈øtolicall ≈øeate vpon no other meaning did tran≈øport the Empire, but that they who did tran≈øport the Empire, did con≈øent thereunto, or el≈øe made declaration that they ≈øhould tran≈øport the ≈øame. But ≈øuch a tran≈øport hath had its power from the vniforme con≈øent of the people.

Hence may very plainely appeare in what maner the tran≈øport which Leo performed was done, and by this meanes that is very ea≈øily ouerthrowne, which they ≈øay:
That the Empire was tran≈øported for Here≈øie: the occa≈øion of the tran≈øport is here formerly related out of Sigibertus: the true cau≈øe thereof was, becau≈øe the Emperours of the Ea≈øt did neglect, or were carele≈ø≈øe of the We≈øterne Empire and authoritie: and ≈øo (as is afore≈øaid) did let it pa≈ø≈øe; this we can confirme and approue with very firme te≈øtimony; Lupoldus ≈øaith in his fourth booke of the rights of the authoritie of the Empire, in this maner. The Grecian Emperour in the time of Carolas Magnus, nay before his time al≈øo, viz. when his Father Pepin, and his Grandfather Carolus Martellus liued, gouerned onely with the name of the We≈øterne Empire: ≈øo that neither the Romi≈øh Church, nor the other Chri≈øtian Congregations, nor tho≈øe of the Longobardes, who were contrary to all law ≈øuppre≈øt, could either by the Ea≈øterne Emperour, nor by their authoritie obtaine any right in the We≈øterne Empire: ≈øo that the afore≈øaid Emperours made no account nor reckoning of the We≈øterne Empire, but held it loo≈øely as a derelict, onely commanding therewith the name, as appeareth in diuers Chronicles; Of the ≈øame opinion is Iohannes Pari≈øien≈øis, in his 16. Chapter, writing of the Kingly and papall power. It was not done by the Pope onely, but that it was the peoples de≈øire, who may ≈øubiect them≈øelues to whom they will, without preiudice to any other: and therefore that was done for a nece≈ø≈øary rea≈øon, for to defend them again≈øt the Heathens and infidels, becau≈øe they could not be defended by any other: which right they might doe: for the people make the King, and the Army the Emperour. Aneas Syluius in his booke of the ri≈øing, and authoritie of the Roman Empire, ≈øaith in the 9. Chap. At the la≈øt when the Grecians were carele≈ø≈øe of Rome, and leauing the ≈øame to be made a pray, and to be ran≈øacked one while by the Barbarians, and al≈øo by others: the people of Rome, who with their blood had got ≈øuch great riches, who by their valour had erected the Monarchie of the
world, ≈øaluted by the name of Emperour, Carolus Magnus then King of the Francks, being a German borne, who deliuered the Citie and the Holy place from the inua≈øion of enemies: fir≈øt greeting him with this title, Patricius: and afterwards Augu≈øtus: the Popes good will and plea≈øure hereunto concurring. Al≈øo ≈øaith Nauelerus in his 27. generat, in the yeare 800, vpon the day of the Birth of our Lord, good deliberation proceeding: Leo the Pope of Rome, con≈øidering that the Con≈øtantinopolitan Emperours did very carele≈ø≈øely defend that name, and held the We≈øterne Empire as lo≈øt: he declared, with the con≈øent of the people of Rome, Charles Emperour of the Romans, and crowned him with the Crowne; when the commonaltie of the Romans three times cried out aloude, Carolo Augu≈øto, &c.

Paulus Aemilius in his Hi≈øtorie of the Francks, ≈øaith thus: The Maie≈øtie of the Emperours was now at this time, and before very ≈ølight; and there after he ≈øaith: the principalle≈øt of the Romans being of another courage and audacitie, gaue their voyces, that the ≈øeate of the Empire being (as it were voyde) and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of none: as if it had beene Gods will, and had beene ≈øo ordained: ≈øhould be inue≈øted with the King of the Francks, becau≈øe that he by his ≈øeruice which he had done for the Church, had well de≈øerued the ≈øame: and that they were obligde and bound to him, &c.

Michaell Coccimus ≈øpeaketh yet more plaine concerning the tran≈øport of the Empire, ≈øaying: When the Romans, and almo≈øt all the people of Italy by proce≈ø≈øe of time, and the Inua≈øion of many Nations and pillagings, as being ≈øubiect to the Gothes, Vice-Gothes, Humes, and Longbardes, and being not able with their owne forces to defend them≈øelues, and the Grecians taking no care at all of them for the performance therof: nay that which is more, they them≈øelues heaping euill vpon euill, and v≈øing all diligence to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe and ≈øpoile them, v≈øing to great auariciou≈øne≈ø≈øe and de≈øire of
authoritie ouer them; they marking the exce≈øsiue couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe of the Grecians, and al≈øo their carele≈øne≈ø≈øe: ob≈øeruing al≈øo the worthine≈ø≈øe, capacitie, and equitie of the Germanes: they tran≈øported the Empire from the Grecians vnto the Germanes, and recommended the ≈øame to Carolus Magnus; This tran≈øport of the Empire being effected by the Romans, and other people of Italy, and that with the common con≈øent and authoritie of them all, out of all doubt had full power, and hath remained firme.
Hence appeareth plaine enough, that they are either fooles, or el≈øe are much deceiued, which thinke that the Empire was tran≈øported to the Francks for here≈øie.

This al≈øo is worthy con≈øideration, that although the Ea≈øterne Empire was tran≈øported by Pope Leo to the We≈øterne, that the Pope hath now the ≈øame right to remoue the Empire according to his will. In olde time it was otherwi≈øe then it is now. Let vs grant that the Pope of Rome had ≈øome right, as the be≈øt qualified citizen of the citie; nay that the City (which neuer yet was done) had tran≈øported all her power vnto him, what doth that concerne the≈øe our pre≈øent times, ≈øince that the Pope hath driuen the Emperour out of the dominion of the Citie. After what manner (≈øay I) hereafter ≈øhall either Rome it ≈øelfe, or the Pope of Rome pretend any right in the electing of an Emperour, ≈øince they doe not acknowledge the Emperour for their Lord; yea ≈øince it is acknowledged that the prince Electors are to be ordained by the con≈øent and voices of the States, and this is by the approbation of Gregory the 5; hath not the Pope lo≈øt his right when he con≈øented hereunto? ≈øo that hereby that authoritie which the Pope a≈øcribeth to him≈øelfe is quite ouerthrowne. What a number of proofes might be produced again≈øt this power of the Pope? yea al≈øo the te≈øtimonie of principall per≈øonages, who by rea≈øon of their learning, are exceeding famous.

Here followeth the third part, which falleth very grieuou≈øly
both with tooth and naile vpon the bodies of all tho≈øe that di≈ølike the ≈øentence of the Pope, and that con≈øi≈øteth in the three la≈øt Articles.

And fir≈øt that is touched which concerneth the election, that is, the right of voice is taken from the Prince Elector the Duke of Saxon; vnder this pretext, becau≈øe for≈øooth the Pope of Rome hath not confirmed that dignitie wherwith that family for the≈øe many yeares hath been inve≈øted, nor is it confirmed by the Pope: as if that illu≈øtrious Family had not been ≈øo wi≈øe, as neuer to haue required the ≈øame of the Pope. It is but too well knowne vnto them, that they whom the Hope glorieth to haue honoured with the name of Empire or Authoritie, that hee taketh away from them the maie≈øtie of authoritie: ≈øo that his inve≈øting may well be called di≈ørobing, and his crowning a dethroning or depo≈øing. For I pray you, of what con≈øequence is the confirmation of the Pope vnto tho≈øe whom he driues into a bodily feare, if he had no temporall power? It is ≈øuch as Origen long ago vnder≈øtood to be; which he taught, as appeareth by his writings vpon Mathew, on his twelfth Homily: Among you which are mine, the≈øe things ≈øhall not be; to the end that tho≈øe which haue any power in the Church, doe not ≈øeeme to domineere ouer their brethren, nor to v≈øe any authoritie. For like as a nece≈øsitie is impo≈øed vpon temporall matters, and not left to the will; and ≈øpirituall matters in will, and not in nece≈øsity: ≈øo ≈øhall the dominion of ≈øpirituall Princes be confirmed in loue, and not in bodily feare. If therefore the power of the prince Electors be from the Pope, becau≈øe that the Emperiall power is from him, as our adver≈øaries affirme: how can they proue that the dignitie of the prince Elector mu≈øt proceed from the Pope, if it be not needfull that the Emperour be confirmed by the Pope? There is a text that ≈øaith, The Army maketh an Emperour. The Glo≈ø≈øe ≈øaith thereby, He is a right Emperour before he be confirmed by the Pope. This they of Ba≈øil
vnder≈øtood very well; who after the death of Lodowicke, where the Lord of Bambergher chiefe Pre≈øident made this an≈øwer: That Emperour which the prince Electors ≈øhall ordaine for vs, him will we accept of, although he haue no re≈øpect vnto the Pope. This appeareth in ≈øupplemento Vr≈øpergen≈øi. Nay that which is more; the Pope him≈øelfe confe≈ø≈øeth, that not the Empire it ≈øelfe, but the Emperiall title re≈øted onely in him. Pope Adrian the fourth, in his Epi≈øtle to the Archbi≈øhop of Ments, Tryer and Cullen, ≈øaith: The name of the Emperour is from the Pope, but the Empire and Authoritie cometh from the prince Electors. Hence then is confuted that which is ≈øaid in the 27. Article, ≈øince that the Pope hath confirmed the Duke of Bavaria in the dignitie of prince Elector, that then not onely the King of Spaine (who is there mentioned) but al≈øo the Emperour is bereaued of the power to re≈øtore againe vnto the Pal≈øgraue his hereditary po≈ø≈øe≈øsions and the dignitie of the prince elector≈øhip. For if the Pope hath no power in the affaires of the Empire, then ≈øhall the Emperour by his doings not lo≈øe his right, much le≈ø≈øe any other Prince, if he before the Popes deed had any right of ≈øuffrage.

I am forced to ≈øtop my eares by the rea≈øon of that extreame proud and ambitious affront which is ≈øet downe in the 28 Article: That although the two mo≈øt pui≈ø≈øant Kings of Great Brittaine and Denmarke, or the two illu≈øtrous prince Electors of Saxon and Brandenburgh ≈øhould require of the Emperour that the Pal≈øgraue of the Rhine might be re≈øtored againe vnto his hereditary po≈ø≈øe≈øsions and dignitie of prince Elector, that they then robbed the Seate of Rome of the right of its maie≈øtie, and did attribute the power of the prince Electors dignitie vnto the Emperour. The Pope of Rome doth very fal≈øly attribute that Maie≈øty vnto him≈øelfe, which appertaineth to the Emperour, and to the Princes of the Empire and the States. Very fal≈øly is the Pope of Rome called here, the Fountaine and Sour≈øe of the prince Electors
dignities, becau≈øe that power is ≈øprung out of the Councell of the Germaine Princes. Like as Naucleius ≈øaith, Generat. 34. The writer Theodoricus Niemus v≈øeth the≈øe words: The Princes of Germanie haue ordained it ≈øo. The very ≈øame al≈øo do other writers affirme. Neither do I deny that it was with the approbatioÃÑ of Pope Gregory the 5. Therefore the temporall dignitie is not chiefely from the Pope, for not the Pope, but the princes of the Empire doe repre≈øent the whole body and people of the Empire, in whom immediatly, as in the ≈øubiect the temporall power con≈øi≈øteth.

Nicholas Cu≈øanus in his third booke of the catholicke concordance, in the 4. Chap. In my iudgement iudgeth very well thereof, writing in this maner, ≈øaith: The prince Electors, who elected in the place of others, were (in the time of Pope Gregory the 5, being a Germaine) ordained of the naturall kindred of Otho and therefore it is not tollerable that the prince Electors ≈øhould haue their power of electing from the Pope of Rome; (≈øo that now, vnle≈ø≈øe he con≈øented the≈øe ≈øhould not haue it: or if he would, that he would take it from them.) I aske, who hath giuen the people of Rome power to elect an Emperour, but the Law of God and nature; for by way of a voluntary ≈øubiection, and con≈øent in predecedencie, all ≈øorts of gouernments are well and holy in≈øtituted: and afterwards there he ≈øetteth downe yet ≈øomething el≈øe; the prince Electors that were con≈øtituted by the generall vniformitie of voices, of all Germaines and others belonging to the Empire: in the time of Henry the 2. had their fundamentall power from the generall con≈øent of voices of all, who by the law of nature might chu≈øe them≈øelues an Emperour, not from the Pope of Rome him≈øelfe, in who≈øe power it is not to giue to euery prouince a King or an Emperour when it plea≈øeth him, and when it doth not plea≈øe him.

La≈øtly, the Articles were ≈øealed vp with this Oath.
That the Pope him≈øelfe, without preiudice to his ≈øeate, may not reuoke the Elector≈øhip from the Duke of Bauaria, ≈øince that he hath confirmed him in that dignitie; nay, that all the Prelates of the Romi≈øh Church, are bound with force of Armes to maintaine the Duke of Bauaria: and yet more, that all tho≈øe that are of the Romi≈øh Church, are bound to bring all their force together to maintaine the ≈øame. So that the Romi≈øh Clergie di≈ødaining the prerogatiue of Kings and Princes, doth very boldly determine and decide the≈øe controuer≈øies which ari≈øe in the Empire, and threatneth to force them by warre who are not content with the Popes ≈øentence; How il≈øauourly the≈øe things doe ≈øute and agree with Pope and Clergie of Rome, is ≈øhewed vnto vs in that famous place of Peter Damianus, who liued in the yeare 1060, his words in his Letter vnto the Bi≈øhop Firminus are the≈øe.

p.q:
Like as the Sonne of God him≈øelfe did ouercome all the ob≈øtacles of this raging world, not by any proofe of vengeance, but by con≈øtant patience, and inuinceable Maie≈øtie: ≈øo ≈øitteth it be≈øt that we rather ≈øuffer, and patiently endure the worlds raging with humilitie: then either by taking Armes in hand, or requiting wounds with wounds: e≈øpeciall ≈øince that betweene the Empire and the Prie≈øt-hood, the offices are ≈øeuerall; The King ≈øhall v≈øe the temporall Armes, the Prie≈øt ≈øhall put on a ≈øpirituall ≈øword, which is the word of God; Paul ≈øaith of the princes of this world, that he beareth not the ≈øword in vaine, being a Mini≈øter of God, and his reuenger in wrath, vpon him that doth euill. King Azarias, becau≈øe he tooke vpon him the Prie≈øts office, was ≈øtricken with Lepro≈øie: ≈øo that Prie≈øts which ≈øhall take vp Armes, (which is the worke of the Laitie) what de≈øerueth he? If now any man would obiect, that Pope Leo oftentimes thru≈øt him≈øelfe into warres, and yet for all that was a iu≈øt Pope: I tell you mine opinion. Peter neuer obtained the Apo≈øtle-≈øhip becau≈øe he for≈øooke
his Ma≈øter; Nor Dauid the gift of prophe≈øing, becau≈øe he defiled anothers mans bed. Here is not to be con≈øidered of good and euill things according to the de≈øert of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors, but they are to be iudged according to their owne qualities. Doe we reade any where that Pope Gregory, who endured ≈øo many roberies and pillages of the Longebeards, either did or wrot the like; Doe we reade any where, that any of the holy and worthy Popes did euer take vp Armes to make a warre: no neuer in no place; grant then that the Lawes of the ciuill Magi≈øtrate may narrowly fift, pry, and determine any certaine que≈øtion which ari≈øeth in the Church: or el≈øe determine and iudge of that which concernes not the Iudgement ≈øeate of the ciuill Magi≈øtrate, by an Edict of the Councell, or an a≈ø≈øembly of Diuines: to the end that either by the iudgement of the Magi≈øtrate, or the Iudicate of the Pope, there ari≈øe no warre which might be accounted to our ≈øhame.

div.p:
The Clergie men of Rome are altogether of another oppinion, practi≈øing and endeauouring almo≈øt nothing el≈øe but warre, not onely with their Armes, but al≈øo threatening others, and whil≈øt they are doing this, they are not a≈øhamed to affirme, that they are bound thereunto by the Lawes of God; Let them ob≈øerue what Chri≈øt commanded the Apo≈øtle Peter, to put vp the ≈øword into the ≈øheath. Where hath euer God commanded the Clergie, that they ≈øhould intermeddle in matters of temporall dignities, or ≈øhould vndertake warres: much le≈ø≈øe that they ≈øhould blow the Trumpet, or beate Allarmes as they do now. (haue I the de≈øire of Dominion their God) Ob≈øerue diligently I pray you, that bloody Oath intended by all the Prelates, to the end the fa≈øhion of the ancient and holy Church might be maintained intire, like as if the fa≈øhion of their Church now were, as it was wont to be in former times; Let vs reade that which Tertullian, Ambro≈øe, Augu≈øtine, and other Writers, who ≈øubiect the Clergie vnder the power of the Temporall; Pope Gregorius
Magnus, writeth him≈øelfe vnto the Emperour Mauritius the≈øe words: I the vnworthy ≈øeruant of your pietie: and a little after he ≈øaith yet farther, To this end authoritie is giuen to me from heauen aboue all men, that belong to my Lords the Emperours for pietie cau≈øe; When as the ≈øaid Mauritius, would haue that Pope Gregory ≈øhould publi≈øh a law which he had made: and this Pope adiudging the ≈øame to be vnrea≈øonable, and oppo≈øing the liberty of the Church: he therefore did not bla≈øpheme again≈øt the Empire, but was obedient vnto the command of the Emperour his Ma≈øter, not di≈ø≈øembling to ≈øpeak his minde and opinion of the Emperours Law: the≈øe are the Popes owne wordes: I being ≈øubiect to authoritie, haue ≈øent the≈øe Lawes into ≈øeuerall quarters of the world, and becau≈øe they are not agreeable to almightie God, I haue communicated the ≈øame vnto the Illu≈øtrou≈øe Lords, by ami≈øsiue of my owne oppinion, ≈øo that I haue fully di≈øcharged my dutie on both ≈øides: ≈øhewing as I am bound obedience to the Emperour: and not concealing my opinion in that which concerneth God.

Here ought we to ob≈øerue, how cunningly and craftily the Colledge of Cardinalls ob≈øerue and aime at the example of the ancient holy Church, chiefly in the time of Pope Gregory the 7: vnder which this lurketh, that this Pope Gregory was the very fir≈øt who dur≈øt a≈øcribe & take vnto him≈øelfe the right of the Empire; At what time (I pray you) liued this Pope? about the yeare 1100. is the antiquitie whereof they boa≈øt; I may affirme with Tertullian, that this is noueltie; what holine≈ø≈øe was there in tho≈øe dayes, when all maner of fractious, cu≈ø≈øennings, frauds, deceites, and villanies had their full ≈øwinge: and to write much thereof would be to dangerous, and be no honour to Chri≈øtendome; Like as the Writer of tho≈øe times affirmeth in the dayes of the Emperor Henry the 4. It is very well knowne vnto all men, what Cardinall Benno hath written and tran≈ølated of that Pope:
(although Cardinall Bellarmine iudgeth that the ≈øame was wrtten by a Lutheran;) In like manner, it is al≈øo but to well knowne by other Writers, who haue painted out in liuely colours this Pope Gregory euen to the life. A certaine man named Orthamus Gracious, very much adicted to the Romi≈øh Church, was the fir≈øt publi≈øher thereof in a booke, wherein are contained very many remarkeable ob≈øeruations: out of the actions of this Pope Gregory, the Colledge of Cardinals, in the 19. Articles do conclude the Popes authoritie, and not out of the≈øe actiones onely, but al≈øo of other Popes who haue delt mo≈øt tirannically with the Empire. One could al≈øo hit the Cardinalls in the teeth, with that which Cardinall Bellarmine in his ≈øecond Booke of the Popes of Rome ≈øaith, in the 29. Chap. vpon the 4. Argument, viz. That the Chri≈øtian Emperours haue oftentimes beene Iudges of the Popes: whereunto very ≈øubtilly he inferreth or an≈øwereth; That the≈øe things haue beene done, but how well they haue done the ≈øame, and by what right, that they them≈øelues ≈øhall an≈øwer.

It is indeed much to be wondred at, that the Clergie men are grown to that pa≈ø≈øe, that they ≈øo ≈øtoutly attempt that which all the world hath in abomination, and with ≈øuch polluted hands to lay hold vpon the mo≈øt famous ≈øtate of the Empire. We ob≈øerue al≈øo how ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe the Colledge of Cardinalls are, willing that we (from the euill liues and wicked actions of decea≈øed Popes) ≈øhould conclude how great the authoritie of the Pope is: at lea≈øt they neede not to be ≈øo contumelious, and arrogant again≈øt tho≈øe Emperours, which in former times the Popes haue acknowledged to be them≈øelues ≈øeruants of the Emperours; The Pope al≈øo ought to haue in con≈øideration that he by meanes of the Empire hath obtained ≈øo great riches, and now by the greatne≈ø≈øe of his power, and all maner of ≈øen≈øuallities, blindeth the eyes of many temporall princes.

How blind are the men of this age, when the Sunne
≈øhineth ≈øo bright, how little do they know or think what will fall out in the end; he hath got ≈øo great trea≈øures from tho≈øe of the Empire, to the end that he wanting nothing, might giue the better lu≈øter vnto his religion: now abu≈øeth he the≈øe gifts, by driuing the Empire into a great feare. He is enriched with earthly countries, to the end he ≈øhould enrich vs with the heauenly, and now they ≈øerue him to take away our earthly; He is enriched, to the end that by his religious care, we might liue in greater ≈øecuritie in the Empire: now he careth not for that, although there be trouble rai≈øed in the Empire, ≈øo he may liue brauely and laciuiou≈øly; This is the reward of peruerted liberalty: ≈øo that for many ages it hath been very truely ≈øaid: Religion brought forth riches, and the Daughter hath deuoured the Mother.

You props and pillers of the Empire, (mo≈øt Illu≈øtrious Emperour, Princes Electors, Princes, and States) tollerate no longer this triumph and pride of the Romi≈øh Clergie: you ≈øee how boldly they violate the lawes of the Empire, they limite your e≈øtabli≈øhed law, and preferre vnto you that which they do but thinke and inuent: leauing vnto you the bare name of the empire, but haue drawne the maie≈øtie thereof long agoe to them≈øelues.

What will this worke in the end, if you be content any longer with patience to behold or looke vpon the ≈øame, neuer thinke that they will omit to increa≈øe theirs, and decrea≈øe yours; You haue heard how they threaten you, and what they intend as enemies to pro≈øecute: and you know that the abominable deeds which the Popes haue performed again≈øt the Emperours, doe ≈øerue them now for very faire examples.

Since then it is not yet to late, take councell prouidently, that the Romi≈øh Cardinalls in the end may be glad to leaue their affronts, and their proud courage may quaile, vndertake firme and ≈øub≈øtantiall cour≈øes, that their di≈ø≈øolute and in≈øolent de≈øire of dominion may be re≈øtrained and bridled: then ≈øhall the Maie≈øtie of the empire be
pre≈øerued: whereunto Almighty God giue you his ble≈øsing in all your con≈øultations. from whom you haue receiued the po≈ø≈øe≈øsion and gouernment of the Empire.
